The Love Actually Comic Relief special will not pay tribute to Alan Rickman. 
Fans of the film had hoped the highly-anticipated cast reunion would honour the late actor, who tragically passed away last year following a battle with cancer. 
However, director Richard Curtis has explained that he has chosen not to do this. 
"You know dealing with Alan is very complicated so not really," he told Press Association. "We’re not [involving] everyone. We’re doing about two thirds of people." The Love Actually Comic Relief special will not pay tribute to Alan Rickman 
Alan played Harry in Love Actually, which was released 13 years ago. Read More First pictures from Love Actually 2 show a VERY grown up Sam 
His character was married to Karen [Emma Thompson] - the sister of the Prime Minister [Hugh Grant] - but he went on to cheat with a young receptionist in his office called Mia. Fans of the film had hoped the highly-anticipated cast reunion would honour the late actor, who tragically passed away last year following a battle with cancer (Photo: Rex) 
After his wife found out, the couple decided to work on their marriage for the sake of their children. 
But it looks like fans will never know whether the couple managed to have a happy ending as Curtis has confirmed that actress Emma will not be appearing in the Comic Relief special either. Director Richard Curtis has explained that he has chosen not to pay tribute to Rickman (Photo: Photo by Buchan/Variety/REX/Shutterstock) 
"Ems isn’t in it. She just can’t do it," he revealed. 
Fortunately for fans, Keira Knightley, Colin Firth, Liam Neeson, Bill Nighy, Andrew Lincoln, Martine McCutcheon and Rowan Atkinson have all signed up to appear in the ten-minute short, Comic Relief Actually.
